introdution.p: A charged object, such as a plastic rod rubbed with a rabbit fur, usually has a large number of charges. To handle thess types of situations, we model them with a continuous charge density. Then, we divide the charge distribution into small cells and replace charges in cells by point charges at their locations, to which we apply methods of discrete charges we learned in .

sidebyside.p: To be specific about the method for handling continuous charges, let us consider finding electric potential at point P by a charge distribution of an arbitrary shape shown in .

introdution.p:
Let \rho represent the charge density. As per our plan we divide up the charged body into cells. Let q_i denote the charge in cell at coordinate (x_i, y_i, z_i). Let \Delta V_i denote the volume of this cell. Then,
q_i = \rho \Delta V_i.
This discretization results in a finite number of charges located at the cells of the body. Let N be the total number of these cells. In we found that potential for N charges is given by
\phi_P = \dfrac{1}{4\pi\epsilon_0}\, \sum_{i=1}^{N} \dfrac{ q_i}{r_i} = \dfrac{1}{4\pi\epsilon_0}\, \sum_{i=1}^{N} \dfrac{ \rho\Delta V_i}{r_i},
where r_i is distance from charge q_i to the field point P. Using Cartesian coordinates (x_i,\ y_i,\ z_i) of charge q_i and field point P (x,\ y,\ z) these distances are
r_i = \sqrt{ (x-x_i)^2 + (y-y_i)^2 + (z-z_i)^2 }.

subsection.title: (Calculus) Electric Potential of a Chsrge Distribution
subsection.p:
In the limit of infinitesimal cells in Eq. , the sum becomes an integral, which we can formally write the result as a coneptual integral.
\phi_P = \frac{1}{4\pi\epsilon_0}\int_{\text{cells}}\frac{dq}{r_{\text{cell-to-P}}},
where r_{\text{cell-to-P}} is the distance to point P from the infinitesimal cell. Note that this is just a concetual integral - in each situation, you will use this equation as a guide and discover the actual integral that you can evaluate to get your answer.

sidebyside.p:
To be concrete, let the position of the space point P be denoted as \vec r and the position of a representative cell element be \vec r^{\prime}, then the integral can be written more explicitly.
\phi_P = \frac{1}{4\pi\epsilon_0}\int_{\text{cells}}\frac{dq}{|\vec r-\vec r^{\prime}|},
where dq refers to the charge in the cell at position \vec r^{\prime}.

exercise.title: (Calculus) Electric Potential of a Uniform Line of Charge

sidebyside.p: Find the electric potential of a uniformly charged non-conducting wire with linear density \lambda (SI units \text{C/m} ) and length L at a point that lies on a line that divides the wire into two equal parts.

hint.p: Place the charged wire along y axis and field point P on the x axis.

solution.p:
We start with identifying a representative cell on the line. This is shown in the figure as an infinitesimal elment at coordinate y. The charge in the cell is dq = \lambda\,dy. From the figure, it is clear that the electric potential of this charge will be
d\phi = \dfrac{1}{4\pi\epsilon_0}\, \dfrac{\lambda\, dy}{\sqrt{x^2 + y^2}}.
Here x is the field point. Therefore, when we sum over (i.e. integrate) the charges, we will keep x fixed. We will get the net potential at (x,0), which is the location of the field point.

exercise.title: Electric Potential of a Uniformly Charged ring

sidebyside.p: A ring of radius R has a uniform charge density \lambda (SI units \text{C/m} ) as shown in . Find the electric potential at a point on the axis of the ring a distance h above the center.

hint.p: This distance to the field point from each element of the ring is same.

solution.p:
Every charge of the ring has the same distance to the field point.
r = \sqrt{R^2 + h^2}.
Therefore, each charge will have the same potential there. Hence, we will get
\phi_P\amp = \dfrac{1}{4\pi\epsilon_0}\, \dfrac{q_\text{tot}}{r} \amp = \dfrac{1}{4\pi\epsilon_0}\, \dfrac{2\pi R \lambda}{\sqrt{R^2 + h^2} }.

exercise.title: (Calculus) Electric Potential of a Uniformly Charged Disk

sidebyside.p: (a) Find the electric potential of a uniformly charged nonconducting disk of radius R with charge density \sigma ( \text{C/m}^2) at a point on the axis as shown in . For concrteteness, let the field point on the axis be at a height h from the center of the disk.

statement.p: (b) Take h/R\rightarrow 0 on your answer to show that very near the disk, potential varies as linearly with h. You should get (\sigma/2\epsilon_0)(R-h) in the leading order in h/R.
(c) Take R/h\rightarrow 0 on your answer to show that very far away from the disk, potential at height h is that of a point charge equal to total charge on the disk.

hint.p: Consider fields of rings of radius r and thickness dr. Utilize superposition.

solution.title: (a)

sidebyside.p:
(a) We will discretize the disk in the shape of rings of thickness dr. One such ring of radius r is shown in . The potential from charges in this infintesimal ring can easily be seen to be
d\phi = \frac{1}{4\pi\epsilon_0}\,\frac{dq}{\sqrt{h^2 + r^2}},
where dq = \sigma \times 2\pi r dr.

solution.title: (b)
solution.p:
(b) To take h/R\rightarrow 0 limit, let us factor out R to get
\frac{\sigma R}{2\epsilon_0}\left( \sqrt{ 1 + (h/R)^2} -h/R\right).
Let us denote h/R = x and then expand \sqrt{1+x^2}\approx 1 + \frac{1}{2}x^2 to get
\frac{\sigma R}{2\epsilon_0}\left( 1 + \frac{1}{2}x^2 - x \right).
Now, noting that when x gets small x \gg x^2. therefore, we drop the quadratic term, but keep the linear term -- since dropping that will get rid of information about h-dependence altogether. Restoring h/R, we get
\frac{\sigma}{2\epsilon_0}\left( R - h \right).

solution.title: (c)
solution.p:
(c) Here we want to take R/h\rightarrow 0. Therefore, we factor out h.
\frac{\sigma h}{2\epsilon_0}\left( \sqrt{ 1 + (R/h)^2} -1\right).
Let x=R/h and expand the square root. Keep upto the leading terms that has h in it, we get
\frac{\sigma h}{2\epsilon_0}\frac{1}{2} \frac{R^2}{h^2}.
Noting that total charge is q_\text{tot}=2\pi R^2\sigma, this is
\frac{1}{4\pi\epsilon_0}\frac{q_\text{tot}}{h}.
That is, far away from the disk, the potential is that of a point charge eaual to total charge placed at the center.
